metadata.case_name: Sri Pajawar Mutt & Ors. v. State of Mysore
metadata.case_number: Civil Appeals Nos. 2222 of 1966, 441 to 444 and 446 of 1970

facts.text: Seven writ petitions filed in Mysore High Court under Art. 226 challenging validity of Mysore Land Revenue Surcharge Act, 1961 (Mysore Act XIII of 1961), as amended by Mysore Acts 1 and 31 of 1963, as ultra vires Constitution.
Petitioners from South Kanara District (part of Madras State prior to reorganisation) and Bellary District; some from Karnatak area of then Bombay State.
In writ petition No. 1137 of 1963 (South Kanara district), petitioner mutt owned immovable properties paying assessment of about Rs. 8,000/- per annum.
Survey and settlement introduced 1902-1904; lands classified into dry, wet, garden; settlement for 30 years; rates fixed, not to be varied during period.
In 1934, after 30 years, rates for garden and wet lands revised and increased by 12 1/2% uniformly; settlement term: no increment during next 30 years.

Madras Legislature levied surcharge in 1954 and 1955 under Madras Land Revenue Surcharge Act, 1954 and Additional Surcharge Act, 1955, but before implementation, South Kanara (except Kasaragod Taluk) integrated into Mysore via States Reorganisation.
By s.119 States Reorganisation Act, lands continued to pay under existing law.
Mysore Land Revenue Surcharge Act, 1961 (Act XIII of 1961) came into force April 1, 1961; levied surcharge of 15 np. per rupee on land revenue for holders paying > Rs.20.
Section 3(2) exempted certain merged territories/areas if revenue fixed by survey under Bombay/Hyderabad laws and equal to or more than in neighbouring villages.
Mysore Land Revenue Surcharge Amendment Act, 1962 effective April 1, 1962; raised surcharge to 100% of land revenue for wet/garden lands, 75% for dry lands for 1962-63 and 1963-64.
Section 5 of 1961 Act: surcharge treated as land revenue, recoverable as such.
Mysore High Court by judgment/order dated September 17, 1965 held Acts within competence of Mysore legislature, not violating Arts. 14, 19 or 31.
Six appeals before Supreme Court; facts focused on South Kanara; common ground: if High Court judgment on South Kanara upheld, others fail.
Land revenue highest in Madras area (half net produce) vs. other areas (1/16th gross produce); assumed correct for argument.
Settlement report received by Government in 1963; resettlement and survey pending, takes long time.

legal_issues.text: Whether Mysore Legislature had competence to enact Mysore Act No.13 of 1961 or amending Act (first ground).
Whether Legislature competent to levy additional land revenue during settlement period (second ground before High Court).
Whether impugned Act ultra vires Art. 19(1)(f) and Art. 31 (third ground before High Court).
Whether levy discriminatory under Art. 14 (fourth ground; confined to this and first before SC).

petitioner_arguments.text: Mysore Legislature had no legislative competence to enact the Acts.
No competence to levy additional land revenue during settlement period.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Mysore Land Revenue Code, 1888; settlement terms

petitioner_arguments.text: Levy discriminatory under Art. 14 due to inequality between South Kanara (ex-Madras) and erstwhile Mysore areas.

respondent_arguments.text: Acts within competence; surcharge is additional land revenue or land tax under Entry 45 or 49 State List.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Entry 45, 49 State List; common practice of surcharges; Art. 271

court_reasoning.text: Surcharge is enhancement of land revenue, squarely within Entry 45; not tax on land revenue; common practice; s.3(1) levies land revenue by surcharge.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Legislation competent; agrees with High Court and Madras High Court in Rajagopalachariar.

court_reasoning.text: Even raising to 100%/75% does not change nature.
No violation of Art. 14; temporary measure on existing rates post-reorganisation while resettlement pending; classification based on intelligible differentia with rational relation.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Distinguishes from other cases; reorganisation justifies differential treatment temporarily (Bhopal Sugar); no arbitrary action.

court_reasoning.text: State needs funds urgently; for Legislature to decide timing, not courts.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No definite time-limit post-reorg for uniformity.

holdings.text: Mysore Legislature competent to enact the impugned Acts.
Impugned Acts do not violate Art. 14.

precedents_cited.case_name: C.Y. Rajagopalachariar v. State of Madras
precedents_cited.relevance: Surcharge as additional land revenue; same view as Mysore HC.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Andhra Pradesh v. Nalla Raja Reddy
precedents_cited.relevance: Tests for Art. 14 classification; temporary surcharge on existing rates does not offend Art. 14; distinguished present case.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Madhya Pradesh v. Bhopal Sugar Industries Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Continuance of old laws post-reorg under s.119 not discriminatory; no fixed time for uniformity.

statutes_cited.name: Mysore Land Revenue Surcharge Act, 1961 (Mysore Act XIII of 1961)
statutes_cited.relevance: Levy of surcharge as land revenue; exemptions; recovery as land revenue.

statutes_cited.name: Mysore Land Revenue Surcharge Amendment Act, 1962
Mysore Land Revenue Code, 1888 (Mysore Act IV of 1888)
Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Competence, equality, property rights; surcharge practice.

statutes_cited.name: States Reorganisation Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Continuance of existing land revenue laws post-reorg.

statutes_cited.name: Madras Land Revenue Additional Surcharge Act, 1955

outcome.summary: Supreme Court upheld Mysore High Court judgment; held Acts within legislative competence and not violative of Art. 14; appeals fail, especially if South Kanara upheld.

key_quotes.text: "The surcharge fell squarely within Entry 45... It is a common practice among the Indian Legislatures to impose surcharge on existing tax."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "We have before us a temporary measure. That is an extremely important circumstance. The State, not unreasonably, proceeded on the basis that a temporary levy could be made on the basis of existing rates."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Justifies no Art. 14 violation as temporary post-reorg.

key_quotes.text: "Continuance of the laws of the old region after the reorganisation by S. 119... was by itself not discriminatory even though it resulted in differential treatment."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: From Bhopal Sugar; supports temporary measures.
